titleStmt.title: The Bloody butcher, and the two wicked and cruel bawds: exprest in a woful narrative of one Nathaniel Smith a butcher, who lived in Maypole-Alley near the Strand; his wife having been all day in the market selling of meat, in the evening went with her husband to an alehouse, where they stay'd till ten of the clock. And then went home together, and being in their lodging, demanded of her the money she had taken that day, but she (being great with child and peevish) refused to give it him, he taking his butchers-knife in his hand stabb'd her in the back, whereof she instantly dyed, for which he was apprehended, condemned, and executed at Tyburn, April the 24th. 1667. : As also another relation of a ravisher, who in a bawdy-house (assisted by two women) ravished a girle. : The tune, The bleeding heart.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 7 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 1 1-bit group-IV TIFF page image.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: The Bloody butcher, and the two wicked and cruel bawds: exprest in a woful narrative of one Nathaniel Smith a butcher, who lived in Maypole-Alley near the Strand; his wife having been all day in the market selling of meat, in the evening went with her husband to an alehouse, where they stay'd till ten of the clock. And then went home together, and being in their lodging, demanded of her the money she had taken that day, but she (being great with child and peevish) refused to give it him, he taking his butchers-knife in his hand stabb'd her in the back, whereof she instantly dyed, for which he was apprehended, condemned, and executed at Tyburn, April the 24th. 1667. : As also another relation of a ravisher, who in a bawdy-house (assisted by two women) ravished a girle. : The tune, The bleeding heart.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed by E. Crowch, for F. Coles, T. Vere, and J. Wright.,

notesStmt.note: Reproduction of original in the Glasgow University Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2008-08 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2008-10 Mona LogarboText and markup reviewed and edited

div.head: The Bloody Butcher, And the two wicked and cruel Bawds:

argument.p:
Expre≈øt in a woful Narrative of one Nathaniel Smith a Butcher, who lived in Maypole-Alley near the Strand; his Wife having been all day in the Market ≈øelling of Meat, in the evening went with her Husband to an Alehou≈øe, where they ≈øtay'd till ten of the clock, and then went home together, and being in their lodging, demanded of her the Money ≈øhe had taken that day, but ≈øhe (being great with child and peevi≈øh) refu≈øed to give it him, he taking his Butchers-knife in his hand ≈øtabb'd her in the back, whereof ≈øhe in≈øtantly dyed, for which he was Apprehended, Condemned, and Executed at Tyburn,
April the 24th. 1667.
As al≈øo another Relation of a Ravi≈øher, who in a Bawdy-hou≈øe (a≈ø≈øi≈øted by two Women) ravi≈øhed a Girle.

lg.l: VVHat horrid execrable Crimes.
Po≈ø≈øe≈øs us in the≈øe latter Times;
Not Pe≈øtilence, nor Sword, nor Fire,
Will make us from our Sins retyre.
Two ≈øad Relations that befel
Vs in this Month, I ≈øhall you tell,
As di≈ømal dreadful D√©eds they be,
As ever you did hear or ≈ø√©e.
One was the Murther of a Wife,
By wrathful Hand, and bloody Knife;
T'other declares tho≈øe that defil'd,
The Virgin body of a Child.
A Butcher, as we under≈øtand,
Liv'd near the May-pole in the Strand;
Nathaniel Smith, who lo≈øt his life,
For the ≈øad ≈ølaughter of his Wife.
After ≈øo many years their hands,
Had b√©en conjoyn'd in wedlock hands,
Whereby came many Children ≈ømall,
One wretched hour confounds them all.
This Butchers Wife did k√©ep a Seat
I' th Market-place to ≈øell her Meat;
And was by all report that's made,
A careful hou≈øe-wife in the Trade.
One fatal Evening being come,
From Market, to her late≈øt home,
She and her Husband both went then,
To a Victualling-hou≈øe and ≈øtaid till ten.
THen went together home, where when
A little ≈øea≈øon they had b√©en;
He in a bold imperious way,
Demands the Coin ≈øhe took that day.
She being with Child, and fretful too,
What he commands ≈øhe would not do;
Which, with his drink, begat a rage,
Nothing but Murther could a≈ø≈øwage.
Words made his pa≈ø≈øion mount up higher
She was the bellows, he the fire:
Words are but wind, but yet they do,
Pierce through the Soul and Body too.
The Devil had ≈øubdued him there,
And whi≈øper'd Murther in his ear;
Which he impatient of delay,
Doth perpetrate the readie≈øt way.
With a ≈øtrong long ≈øharp-poynted knife,
Into the back he ≈øtabs his wife:
Fle≈øh of his fle≈øh, bone of his bone
With one dead-doing blow is gone.
She faltred, fainted, fell down dead,
Vpon the ground her bloud was ≈øhed;
The little Infant in the womb
Received there both Life and Toomb.
Then was he Apprehended, by
Some Neighbours that did hear her cry
Out Murther, murther, and for this,
He judg ‚Ä¢ d and Executed is.
Let this a warning be to tho≈øe,
Who≈øe Pa≈ø≈øions are their greate≈øt Foes:
And let all Women have a care,
To ≈øtir tho≈øe that impatient are.
Ten angry words with wrath and Knife,
Has kil'd a Husband and a Wife;
An Infant too, which makes up Thr√©e,
And ruin'd a whole Family.
But mi≈øchiefs ≈øeldome come alone,
My Mu≈øe hath yet another Groan;
A ≈øigh, a tear, and much of moan,
To tell a D√©ed but lately done.
There was one Mary, a grand Bawd,
That liv'd by Lechery and Fraud;
A≈ø≈øi≈øted by her Daughter Be≈øs,
Did k√©ep a hou≈øe of wickedne≈øs.
They liv'd at We≈øtmin≈øter, where they,
Many a Virgin did betray:
Who≈øe wicked actions made them rue,
This Fact they did, which I'le tell you.
It ≈ø√©ems a Fellow thither came,
To pacifie his lu≈øtful flame;
Having a fire of Drink before,
Came to be quenched by a Whore.
They being de≈øtitute, did m√©et,
A Neighbours Daughter in the ≈øtr√©et;
A pretty Child, and as 'tis told,
By many, but of Ten years old.
Yet ≈øhe is tempted in by them,
To ≈øerve their turn in that extream,
And then deliver'd up to One,
Was more a Devil than a Man.
Vnto this weak unwary Child,
That was unfit to be defil'd;
In order to their ba≈øe De≈øign,
They give it Brandy, Ale, and Wine.
Their hot Gue≈øt for a Wench doth call,
They brought him One, but very ≈ømall;
It ≈øerv'd his turn, and he did fly,
At his ≈ømall Game, they ≈øtanding by,
The Child re≈øi≈øted and cryed out,
The old Bawd choak'd her with a Clout
Stop'd in the mouth; the Fellow ≈øpoil'd,
With furious lu≈øt the fainting Child.
The Fellow having Ravi≈øhed,
This tender Child, away he fled:
But what he was, or who, is known
Not as I hear, to any one.
The two that held, and ≈øtopt her breath,
Mo≈øt ju≈øtly now have ≈øuffer'd Death;
Much pitty 'tis that he is fr√©e'd,
By flight, that did the filthy D√©ed.
Thus have I told you Two ≈øad Crimes,
Committed in the≈øe wor≈øt of Times;
Let all that hear me now, by this,
Take warning not to do ami≈øs.
Return to God, reform your Lives,
Men be not bitter to your wives:
Wives love your Husbands, for bad words
Have drawn a hundred thou≈øand ≈øwords.
Let Love and Patience both agr√©e,
To k√©ep us all in Amity;
Then all our bloody Broyls will cea≈øe,
God ≈øave the King, and ≈øend us Peace.

div.p: With Allowance. London, Printed by E. Crowch, for F. Coles, T. Vere, and J. Wright.
